filters.name: Earthquakes in Canada 2.5 Magnitude and Above (1600-2019)

config.editorDescription: Search for an address, set current location, or locate on map

about.aboutContent:
Â 

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Welcome toÂ 

Â  Â  Â  Â eastQUAKEs Near You!


Â This appÂ helps Eastern Canadians identify earthquakes thatÂ have happened near their communities. The purpose of eastQUAKE is to raise awareness of earthquake vulnerability in Eastern Canada.

Feeling an earthquake has to do with a few main variables: your proximity to the epicentre, the depth of where the rupture occurs in the earth, and the earthquake's magnitude. Shallow, high magnitude earthquakes that are near areas with high populations are most likely to be felt and cause significant damage. This web app allows Eastern Canadians to learn if they live within a certain distance from a past earthquake that was higher than 2.5 magnitude.Â 
Click on theÂ Â button to learn more about what each magnitude means.
Â 

Â  Â Scroll down to learn more about our features!



Â  Â Earthquakes Near Me?Â 
  • Eastern Canadians are often unaware that they live in a seismically active zone where earthquakes have and will happen.
  • This feature allows users toÂ define a buffer radius around any Eastern Canadian address (or your current location) to view which earthquake events have happened near you.
  • The user is prompted to enter their address, enable their current location, or drop a pin to locate earthquakes near them and display the time and date they happened, their magnitude, and a description of the place.
  • Default search radius is 50 km, user can scroll the bar to increase or decrease from 1 km to 100 km.
  • This tool is meant for Eastern Canadians to realize whether or not they live near an area where an earthquake has occurred.

Â  Â Major CitiesÂ 
  • This feature displays 10 major Eastern Canadian cities that, when clicked, automatically takes users to their chosen city.
Â  Â Filter by MagnitudeÂ Â 

  • Users can filter the magnitudes of the earthquakes in order to view whatever range they would prefer to see between 2.5 and 7.2

Â Â What's displayed on the map?Â Â 
  • The Earthquakes layer displays all earthquakes that are greater than or equal to 2.5 magnitude that have occurred in Eastern Canada from 1600 to 2019.
  • The Major Eastern Canadian Cities layer displays a marker for 10 populous cities in Eastern Canada; at least 1 from each province.
  • The Population Density layer displays Eastern Canada's 2016 population divided by the census tract areas (kmÂ squared), from dark red (high population density) to white (low population density).

Earthquakes are quantified based on the energy they emit. The most common are the Richter scale or the Moment Magnitude scale, which both quantify earthquakes from 1 to 10. These scales are logarithmic, which means between each number of the scale corresponds to a 10x increase in amplitude and approximatelyÂ 30 timesÂ increase in energy!

What do the numbers mean in terms of earthquake effects?

Under 2.5Â  -Â  Rarely felt, but recorded on seismographs.

2.5 to 5.4Â  -Â  Often felt, causes minor damages.

5.5 to 6.0Â  -Â  Slight damage to well-designed buildings. Can cause major damage to poorly constructed buildings

6.1 to 6.9Â  -Â  Can be destructive up to 100 km from epicentre, especially in areas with high population density

7.0 to 7.9Â  -Â  Major earthquake causing serious damage over large areas

8 or Greater - Great earthquake able to destroy communities near the epicentre, up to several hundreds of kilometres away.
